column2: 'It must be getting very late, father; I had better go to my room. But, father, you are not comfortable here; sleep in my room; let me sleep here.'

column2: 'Let you sleep here, my daughter--sleep up here among the servants!'

column2: 'Everything in the world is dependent on money.

column2: 'I'm not disturbing you, father?'

column2: 'No, dear: you never disturb me,' he said, getting up from the type- writer and giving her his chair.

column3: 'But what is the matter?'

column2: 'I shan't be many minutes before I finish this lot,' he said; 'then we shall be able to talk.

column2: I promised to get them finished this evening.'

column2: She had never seen a type-writing machine at work before, and admired the nimbleness with which his fingers struck the letters, and the dexterity with which he passed fresh sheets of paper under the roller. When he had finished and was gathering the sheets together, she said,--
column3: She had never seen a type writing machine at work before, and admired the nimbleness with which his fingers struck the letters, and the dexterity with which he passed fresh sheets of paper under the roller. When he had finished and was gathering the sheets together, she said,--

column2: 'How clever you are.'
column3: 'How clever you are.'

column2: 'I think I picked it up pretty quickly.
column3: 'I think I picked it up pretty quickly.

column2: I can do seventy words a minute.
column3: I can do seventy words a minute.

column2: Some typists can do eighty, but my fingers are too old for that.
column3: Some typists can do eighty, but my fingers are too old for that.

column2: Still, seventy is a good average, and I have hardly any corrections to make.
column3: Still, seventy is a good average, and I have hardly any corrections to make.

column2: They are very pleased with my work....
column3: They are very pleased with my work....

column2: I'll teach you--you'd soon pick it up.'
column3: I'll teach you-you'd soon pick it up.'

column2: Then I should be able to assist you.
column3: Then I should be able to assist you.

column2: We could sit together, you in that corner, I in this.
column3: We could sit together, you in that corner, I in this.

column2: I wonder if mother would buy me a machine.
column3: I wonder if mother would buy me a machine.

column2: I could pay her back out of the money I earned, just like you.'
column3: I could pay her back out of the money I earned, just like you.'

column2: 'Your mother would say you were wasting your time.

column2: You've come home, she'd say, to go into society, and not to learn type-writing.'
column3: You've come home, she'd say, to go into society, and not to learn type writing.'

column2: 'I'm afraid she would.

column2: But father, there is no use my going into society.

column2: I shall never get on in society.

column2: Last night at Lord Chiselhurst's----'
column3: Last night at Lord Chiselhurst's----'

column2: 'Yes; tell me about it.

column2: You must have enjoyed yourself there.'
column3: You must have enjoyed yourself there.'

column2: Agnes did not answer for a long while, at last she said,--
column3: Agnes did not answer for a long while, at last she said,--

column2: 'There's something, father, dear, that I must speak to you about.... Mother thinks I ought to marry Lord Chiselhurst, that I ought to make up to him and catch him if I can.
column3: 'There's something, father, dear, that I must speak to you about.... Mother thinks I ought to marry Lord Chiselhurst, that I ought to make up to him and catch him if I can.

column2: She says that he likes very young girls, and that she could see that he liked me.
column3: She says that he likes very young girls, and that she could see that he liked me.

column2: But, father, I cannot marry him.
column3: But, father, I cannot marry him.

column2: He is--no, I cannot marry him.
column3: He is-no, I cannot marry him.

column2: I do not like him, I'm only sixteen, and he's forty or fifty.
column3: I do not like him, I'm only sixteen, and he's forty or fifty.

column2: But that isn't the reason, at least not the only reason.
column3: But that isn't the reason, at least not the only reason.

column2: I don't want to marry any one, and mother doesn't seem to understand that.

column2: She said if that were so, she really didn't see why I left the convent.'
column3: She said if that were so, she really didn't see why I left the convent.'

column2: She was too intent on what she was saying to notice the light which flashed in the Major's eyes.
column3: She was too intent on what she was saying to notice the light which flashed in the Major's eyes.

column2: 'I said, "Mother, I never wanted to leave the convent, it was you who wanted me home." "No," she said, "it was not I, it was your father. But now that you are here I should like you to make a good marriage." Then she turned and kissed me....
column3: 'I said, "Mother, I never wanted to leave the convent, it was you who wanted me home." "No," she said, "it was not I, it was your father. But now that you are here I should like you to make a good marriage." Then she turned and kissed me....

column2: I don't want to say anything against mother; she loves me, I'm sure: but we're so different, I shall never understand mother, I shall never get on in society.
column3: I don't want to say anything against mother; she loves me, I'm sure: but we're so different, I shall never understand mother, I shall never get on in society.

column2: I cannot, father, dear, I cannot, I feel so far away; I do not know what to say to the people I meet.
column3: I cannot, father, dear, I cannot, I feel so far away; I do not know what to say to the people I meet.

column2: I do not feel that I understand them when they speak to me; I am far away, that is what I feel; I shall never get over that feeling; I shall not succeed, and then mother will get to hate me.... I am so unhappy, father, I'm so unhappy.'
column3: I do not feel that I understand them when they speak to me; I am far away, that is what I feel; I shall never get over that feeling; I shall not succeed, and then mother will get to hate me.... I am so unhappy, father, I'm so unhappy.'

column2: Agnes dropped on her knees, and throwing her arms on her father's shoulder, she said:
column3: Agnes dropped on her knees, and throwing her arms on her father's shoulder, she said:

column2: 'But, father, you're not listening.
column3: 'But, father, you're not listening.

column2: Listen to me, I've only you.'
column3: Listen to me, I've only you.'

column2: 'I'm thinking.'
column3: 'I'm thinking.'

column2: 'Of what?'
column3: 'Of what?'

column2: 'Of many things.'
column3: 'Of many things.'

column2: 'Poor father, you have a great deal to think of, and I come interrupting your work.
column3: 'Poor father, you have a great deal to think of, and I come interrupting your work.

column2: How selfish I am.'
column3: How selfish I am.'

column2: 'No, dear, you're not selfish....
column3: 'No, dear, you're not selfish....

column2: I'm very glad you told me.
column3: I'm very glad you told me.

column2: So you think you'll never get on in society.'
column3: So you think you'll never get on in society.'

column2: 'I don't think I'm suited for society.'
column3: 'I don't think I'm suited for society.'

column2: 'I'm afraid you think that all society is like our drawing-room?'
column3: 'I'm afraid you think that all society is like our drawing room?'

column2: 'How was it, father, that our drawing-room came to be what it is?'
column3: 'How was it, father, that our drawing room came to be what it is?'

column2: 'A great deal of it is my fault, dear.
column3: 'A great deal of it is my fault, dear.

column2: When I lost my money I got disheartened, and little by little I lost control.
column3: When I lost my money I got disheartened, and little by little I lost control.

column2: One day I was told that as I paid for nothing I had no right to grumble.
column3: One day I was told that as I paid for nothing I had no right to grumble.

column2: Your mother said, in reply to some question about me, that I was "merely an expense." I believe the phrase was considered very clever, it went the round of society, and eventually was put into a play.
column3: Your mother said, in reply to some question about me, that I was "merely an expense." I believe the phrase was considered very clever, it went the round of society, and eventually was put into a play.

column2: And that is why I told you that money is everything, that it is difficult to be truthful, honourable, or respectable if you have no money, a little will do, but you must have a little, if you haven't you aren't respectable, you're nothing, you become like me, a mere expense.... I've borne it for your sake, dearest.'
column3: And that is why I told you that money is everything, that it is difficult to be truthful, honourable, or respectable if you have no money, a little will do, but you must have a little, if you haven't you aren't respectable, you're nothing, you become like me, a mere expense.... I've borne it for your sake, dearest.'

column2: 'For my sake, father, what do you mean?'
column3: 'For my sake, father, what do you mean?'

column2: 'Never mind, best not to ask....
column3: 'Never mind, best not to ask....

column2: My dearest daughter, I would bear it all over again for your sake.
column3: My dearest daughter, I would bear it all over again for your sake.

column2: But it is maddening work, it goes to the head at last.
column3: But it is maddening work, it goes to the head at last.

column2: It makes one feel as if something was giving way there,' he said, touching his forehead, 'it does indeed.'
column3: It makes one feel as if something was giving way there,' he said, touching his forehead, 'it does indeed.'

column2: 'But, father, you mustn't bear this any longer, not for my sake, father, no, not for my sake; you must find some way out of it.'
column3: 'But, father, you mustn't bear this any longer, not for my sake, father, no, not for my sake; you must find some way out of it.'

column2: 'I have found a way out of it.
column3: 'I have found a way out of it.

column2: It took me a long while, but I have found the way--there it is,' he said, pointing to the type-writing machine.

column2: 'They don't suspect anything, not they, the fools; they don't know what is hanging over their heads.

column2: I'll tell you, Agnes, but you must not breathe a word of it to any one, if you did, they would take the machine from me: for they'd like me to remain a mere expense.
column3: I'll tell you, Agnes, but you must not breathe a word of it to any one, if you did, they would take the machine from me: for they'd like me to remain a mere expense.

column2: As long as I'm that, they can do what they like, but as soon as I gain an independence, as soon as I am able to pay for my meals,' he whispered, 'I mean to put my house in order But you mustn't breathe a word.'
column3: As long as I'm that, they can do what they like, but as soon as I gain an independence, as soon as I am able to pay for my meals,' he whispered, 'I mean to put my house in order But you mustn't breathe a word.'

column2: 'I shall be able to sweep out all those you don't like.

column2: He thinks me crazy, but so do others; I know that my conversation bores him, he always tries to get away from me, yet somehow it seems to me that I do like him.'
column3: He thinks me crazy, but so do others; I know that my conversation bores him, he always tries to get away from me, yet somehow it seems to me that I do like him.'

column2: 'Is he a fast man, father, is he like Lord Chiselhurst?'
column3: 'Is he a fast man, father, is he like Lord Chiselhurst?'

column2: 'He is much the same as the other men that come here.

column2: I don't think he's a bad man--no worse than other men.
column3: I don't think he's a bad man-no worse than other men.

column2: Is he kind to you, dear; tell me that; do you like him?'
column3: Is he kind to you, dear; tell me that; do you like him?'

column2: 'Yes, father; he and Mr. St. Clare are the men I like best here.
column3: 'Yes, father; he and mr saint Clare are the men I like best here.

column2: But why is he here so much, father, he's no relation.'
column3: But why is he here so much, father, he's no relation.'

column2: 'He has dined and lunched here every day for the last ten years.
column3: 'He has dined and lunched here every day for the last ten years.

column2: He's been an expense too.'
column3: He's been an expense too.'

column2: 'Mother said he is so poor that she has often to lend him money.'
column3: 'Mother said he is so poor that she has often to lend him money.'

column2: 'He should have spent some of the money she lent him, on a type- writing machine, and striven as I do to make an independence.

column2: When I've got together a little independence, when I can pay for my meals and my clothes, you shall see; none that you dislike shall ever come here, dearest.

column2: I'll put my house in order.'
column3: I'll put my house in order.'

column2: 'But that will take a long time, father; in the meantime----'
column3: 'But that will take a long time, father; in the meantime----'

column2: 'What, dear?'
column3: 'What, dear?'

column2: 'Mother will want me to marry.'
column3: 'Mother will want me to marry.'

column2: 'They shall not force you to marry, they shall not ask you to do anything you do not like.
column3: 'They shall not force you to marry, they shall not ask you to do anything you do not like.

column2: Lord Chiselhurst ought to be ashamed, a man of his age to want to marry a young girl like you.
column3: Lord Chiselhurst ought to be ashamed, a man of his age to want to marry a young girl like you.

column2: I will go and tell him so.'

column2: The Major stood up, he was pale, and Agnes noticed that his lips trembled.

column2: 'No, father,' she said, 'do not go to him; I do not know that he wants to marry me; it is only mother's idea, she may be mistaken.'

column3: 'You shall not be persecuted by his attentions.'

column2: 'Lord Chiselhurst is a gentleman, father.

column2: Who is it that you wish me to rid you of?'

column2: 'That man--he, too, is merely an expense.'
column3: 'That man-he, too, is merely an expense.'

column2: That fellow--that fellow!'

column2: 'Yes; he asks me questions.'
column3: 'Yes; he asks me questions.'

column2: 'He never shall do so again.

column2: Is he in the drawing-room?'
column3: Is he in the drawing room?'

column2: 'I don't care who's there.'
column3: 'I don't care who's there.'

column2: Mother will never forgive me.... Father, you mustn't make a scene.

column2: Father, you cannot go to the drawing-room in those clothes,' and in desperate resolve, Agnes threw herself between the Major and the door, pressing him back with both hands.

column3: 'They think me a sheep, I have been a sheep too long, but they shall see that even the sheep will turn to save its lamb from the butcher. I'll go to them, yes, and in these clothes-Agnes, let me go.'

column2: But not now, this is not the time.'

column2: He tried to push past her, but she resisted him, and sat down in front of his type-writing machine, pale and exhausted, the sweat pearling his bald forehead.

column2: She tried to calm him and to induce him to understand the scandal he would make if he were to go down to the drawing-room, dressed as he was.
column3: She tried to calm him and to induce him to understand the scandal he would make if he were to go down to the drawing room, dressed as he was.

column2: But her words did not seem to reach the Major's brain.
